Actually, since the printing press was invented in Germany, most presses were made there (then later in Italy also) and British people sent books they wanted to copy and it had þ in it but the Germans didn't know what this strange new letter is. But in calligraphy, þ looked pretty similar to Y, as Y was used in German and þ was in English so Germans used Y instead of þ because it looked the same and then English people started using Y instead of þ.
So we kind of forgot about a letter and accidentally killed it from English. As we also killed ð (eth) and ſ (ss/ß) but Iceland is still using þ and ð because the news of þ dying didn't really get to them because Iceland is a cold foreign land to the rest of Europe (but they (Vikings) also accidentally discovered the new world so...)
So in Icelandic, þ and ð are still used as the same sound but not really. þ is used for TH sounds like "The", and ð was used for sounds like "This"
Example: þe map says I go ðis way.
How the Germans wrote it: ye map says I go this way.

The 'th' sound was actually spelt two ways, þ for the voiced dental fricative eg. 'thy' and ð for the voiceless counterpart 'thigh'. The French have never invaded us (England), it was Normandy which was a separate kingdom at the time (and France didn't adopt the tri colour flag until the French Revolution) and when they heard our alien sounds and letters, they couldn't tell the difference between the sounds and replaced the letters with a normal looking alternative. Although the thorn stuck around for a while and that is why it was substituted for y when printing presses came along not because it was more compact. Could be mistaken, but this has to do with the pre 19th century ambiguity of u and v. Some old alphabet tablets used in schools of the time actually had the two switched, but named as they are now. V was u and u was v. So w was a "double u." This is visible in some museums, the spelling is instead "mvsevm" in the name. At some point in the 19th century the current standard of the alphabet was created. I guess the name was just a holdover from the past.

Er, no. Not at all. Language simplification is by no means "degeneration;" there's nothing negative or positive about it. Language just has a propensity to simplify (phonetically, grammatically, etc.). Even Old English had simplified greatly from its Proto-Germanic parent (fewer distinct case endings), and would continue to simplify right up until the end of the period. For example: early OE: "cyni", late OE: "cyne"; early OE: "hlabweard"; late OE: "hlaford"; early OE "cyning"; late OE: "cyng".

To actually answer your question, they didn't think it looked close. It was just an organic/progressive simplification of the character that is evident in texts as far back as the 14th century. It just so happens that this "new", simpler thorn looked almost stroke for stroke like a "y", so when it came time to introduce the printing press, that's what they used.

Ye also was used for formal 2nd person... was ye and you for the formal case.  And informal (friendly) thou.   Thou was also changed in cases of oblique or accusative for thee. No, 'thou' is the informal version of 'you'. If you've studied Spanish, Italian, French, etc, you notice that they have formal and informal (e.g. the word 'you', informal tú and formal usted, in spanish). English has the same thing. Thou is the informal version of you. We think of it as a more formal version, as that is what the King James Bible used.

Yes and no. Originally, english used to have 2 words to address someone with: Thee and Thou. Thee was first person (at a certain person) while thou was second person (Thou shall not boogie = All of you shall not boogie). Overtime thou because you and thee became you and that's why people same All of you or y'all.

actualy, 'þu' or 'thou' are the two forms of 2nd person singular nominative, and 'you' used to be the dative form of þu (as in 'to you'), but plural. Under the influence of French, people started using 'you' to address a single person, out of respect. Until it totally replaced þu and thou
